title: 107_hr3022
content: The Act is titled the "Temporary Unemployment Compensation Act of 2001." It pertains to Federal-State agreements. The "Temporary Unemployment Compensation Act of 2001" allows states to enter agreements with the Secretary of Labor for unemployment benefits. States can terminate the agreement with 30 days' notice. The agreement includes provisions for regular and supplemental unemployment compensation. The Temporary Unemployment Compensation Act of 2001 allows states to enter agreements with the Secretary of Labor for unemployment benefits. Individuals must meet specific criteria to qualify for extended compensation under the Act. The Temporary Unemployment Compensation Act of 2001 allows states to enter agreements with the Secretary of Labor for unemployment benefits. An individual may be eligible for regular compensation based on specific criteria, including the base period used for determining benefits. The Temporary Unemployment Compensation Act of 2001 allows individuals to receive regular compensation for part-time work. The amount of compensation is determined by the State law, with an additional 15 percent or $25, whichever is greater. The nonreduction rule may apply to a State under certain conditions. The nonreduction rule may cease to apply to a State if the method for calculating regular compensation is modified in a way that results in lower weekly payments than what would have been received under the State law prior to September 11, 2001. Coordination rules also apply to federal benefits based on the modified calculations. Extended benefits shall not be payable if temporary supplemental unemployment compensation is being received. An individual exhausts their regular compensation rights when they have received all available payments based on their employment or wages during the base period. Weekly Benefit Amount for Temporary Supplemental Unemployment Compensation (TSUC) is equal to regular compensation under State law for total unemployment during the benefit year. Terms and conditions of State law apply to claims for TSUC. The maximum amount of temporary supplemental unemployment compensation for an individual shall not exceed the amount in their account established under section 3. SEC. 3. TEMPORARY SUPPLEMENTAL UNEMPLOYMENT COMPENSATION ACCOUNT. The State must establish a temporary supplemental unemployment compensation account for eligible individuals filing for benefits. The account amount is based on a percentage of regular compensation or 13 times the weekly benefit amount. The State law provides allowances for total unemployment, with a rule of construction for benefit computations. SEC. 4. PAYMENTS TO STATES HAVING AGREEMENTS UNDER THIS ACT. Under this Act, States with agreements will receive payments equal to 100 percent of regular compensation for individuals based on specified modifications. This includes compensation paid due to state law provisions comparable to the modifications. Under the Act, States with agreements will receive payments equal to 100 percent of regular compensation for individuals based on specified modifications, including compensation paid due to state law provisions. The amounts payable to States will be determined by the Secretary in advance or by reimbursement, based on estimated entitlements for each calendar month. Estimates will be adjusted for any discrepancies from prior months. The Act allows States with agreements to receive payments equal to 100 percent of regular compensation for individuals. The Secretary will determine the amounts payable to States in advance or by reimbursement based on estimated entitlements for each month. $500,000,000 is appropriated from the Unemployment Trust Fund for administrative expenses and reemployment services for States with agreements under the Act. Each State's share of the appropriation will be determined by the Secretary according to specified factors. The Act provides financing provisions for States with agreements to receive payments equal to 100 percent of regular compensation for individuals. $500,000,000 is appropriated from the Unemployment Trust Fund for administrative expenses and reemployment services for States with agreements under the Act. Each State's share of the appropriation will be determined by the Secretary according to specified factors. The Act allocates funds from the Unemployment Trust Fund for payments to States with agreements under the Act. The Secretary certifies payments to each State, transferring funds from the extended unemployment compensation account or the Federal unemployment account. The Act transfers funds from the Unemployment Trust Fund to States with agreements under the Act. SEC. 6. FRAUD AND OVERPAYMENTS. If an individual knowingly makes a false statement or fails to disclose a material fact to receive undeserved compensation under this Act, they will be ineligible for further benefits and may face prosecution under section 1001 of title 18, United States Code. Repayment is required for those who received undeserved compensation. The State may require individuals to repay benefits received under this Act if they were not entitled to them, unless it was without fault on their part and repayment would be unfair. The State agency can recover the amount by deducting from future unemployment compensation. During a 3-year period, individuals may have to repay any overpaid unemployment benefits, with deductions not exceeding 50% of the weekly benefit amount. Repayment cannot be required until a fair hearing has been provided and a final determination made. Any determination by a State agency under this section shall be subject to review in the same manner and to the same extent as determinations under the State unemployment compensation law. SEC. 7. DEFINITIONS. The terms related to compensation, benefit year, base period, State, State agency, State law, and week are defined under the Federal-State Extended Unemployment Compensation Act of 1970. State law and regular compensation are interpreted based on agreements made under this Act. The Federal-State Extended Unemployment Compensation Act of 1970 defines terms like compensation, benefit year, base period, State, State agency, State law, and week. "Regular compensation" is determined under State law unless specified otherwise. SEC. 8. APPLICABILITY. An agreement under this Act applies to unemployment weeks starting after the agreement date and ending before January 1, 2003. Specific rules include exceptions for alternative base periods, part-time employment, increased benefits, and temporary supplemental unemployment compensation. The agreement under this Act applies to unemployment weeks after the agreement date until January 1, 2003, with exceptions for individuals exhausting regular compensation after September 11, 2001.
